Description.En:
This module is structured in two main parts, covering two important aspects of quantum computing: communication and computation.

The communication part focuses on a secure quantum communication protocol, BB84. You'll be asked to understand and implement this protocol, and even to experiment with an actual demonstrator. The computation part introduces all the basic building blocks of computation, focusing on the Grover search algorithm. This search algorithm makes an explicit link with classical computing while demonstrating the advantages of quantum computers.

By the end of this module, you will have acquired a basic knowledge of quantum computing and communication that we hope will motivate you to take the next step into this dynamic field of computer science.

NoteLiteral.En: Explain protocols relevant to quantum communication as well as their importance.

Title.En: Implement and use a simple quantum algorithm in the context of computing or communication.

NoteLiteral.En: Understand algorithms such as the Grover search algorithm.

Title.En: Explain the benefits of quantum computing.

NoteLiteral.En: Articulate the potential benefits of this cutting-edge techology, particularly regarding communication.

LegalName.En: INSTITUT NATIONAL DES SCIENCES APPLIQUEES DE TOULOUSE (INSA TOULOUSE)

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**Format and Structure**

This micromodule is taught 100% online with the exception of an optional mobility week in INSA Toulouse. The online learning spans from February to the end of May, and is divided into two parts.

The first part is dedicated to communication and the second to calculation. Both parts are organized in the same way.

Each part consists of a series of reading documents and watching associated illustrating the concepts covered. What's more, to make your learning more concrete, a number of notebooks are provided to help you crystallise and develop your understanding.

Your online self-paced learning is supported by live sessions with your teachers. Synchronous teaching takes place in the middle and at the end of each part of the module. Please note the following dates and times for your online live sessions:

- 13th February 2025 - 2-3:30pm CET - Welcome and Introduction to the Micromodule
- 27th February 2025 - 2-3:30pm CET
- 27th March 2025 - 2-3:30pm CET
- 24th April 2025 - 2-3:30pm CET
- 29th May 2025 - 2-3:30pm CET

These dates and time are subject to change.

**Optional Mobility Week**

For those who can, a one-week stay at INSA Toulouse in June will enable you to work directly on a demonstrator. You will receive an extra ECTS credit for attending the mobility week (3 ECTS instead of 2 for the online learning). If you're interested in pariticpating in the optional mobility week, please contact the ECIU mobility officers for details of the procedures to apply for a mobility grant by using the Contact Us form at the bottom of this page. Choose the option "I have a question on mobility support". Your request will be directed to a mobility officer located at your University and you will be contacted with the information you need.

**Assessment**

There are two types of assessment in this micromodule: formative (informal assessment that will help you and your teachers assess your progress) and summative (a final assessment that will allow you to pass the micromodule).

The formative assessment is through multiple-choice quizzes taken online. You will also receive feedback from the notebook implementation exercises.

The summative assessment is a final multiple-choice quiz.

Title.En: Visualization of some transformations using a simple simulator

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
Quantum computing is an emerging field driving the race for the most powerful computer. The innovations brought by quantum computing are intriguing and fascinating. By enabling new computing paradigms, we can solve problems not currently tractable on modern supercomputers. Possible applications range from security to AI.
However, to fully understand the benefits of such a computing device, it is necessary to start from the basics. This module helps to demystify this fascinating field of computer science.

This micromodule is open to all ECIU students in a scientific field who have an interest in learning about quantum computing and communication.

Potential applicants are required to submit a CV, transcript, and a copy of their ID card or student ID.
